title: Exclusive: The Hundred facing criticism over junk food sponsorship
text:
The England and Wales Cricket Board faced criticism from health campaigners on Thursday night after allowing its new fast-paced domestic cricket format to be dominated by a junk food sponsor.

All teams will carry advertising for either crisps, popcorn or nuts as part of a lucrative deal with KP Snacks and the Hundred, a city-based short-form contest fronted on Thursday by England stars Jofra Archer and Jason Roy.

The ECB, which arranged the sponsorship package centrally, believes the controversial snack brand deal will help the Hundred in its bid to reach younger urban audiences at a time of declining county ground attendances.

However, several health campaigners questioned the wisdom of allowing new teams to carry the logos of Skips, Hoola Hoops and McCoy's crisps during Britain's obesity epidemic.

“Quite frankly we’re stumped as to why the English Cricket Board would consider a salty, high fat snacking brand as an appropriate partner for The Hundred," said Barbara Crowther, of the Children’s Food Campaign. "The ECB should be swinging behind the government target for halving childhood obesity by 2030, not becoming complicit with junk food industry spin.”
description: The England and Wales Cricket Board faced criticism from health campaigners on Thursday night after allowing its new fast-paced domestic cricket format to be dominated by a junk food sponsor.
